Trans-Alaska Trail
Home About Documents Subscribe

Photo Credit: Austin Love

About

The idea for the Trans-Alaska Trail originates from the office of Representative Jonathan Kreiss-Tomkins, where planning began in November 2014. The team of collaborators has since grown across Alaska and the Lower 48.

A huge cadre of people — agency staff and leadership at Alaska DNR and BLM, GIS techs at the University of Alaska Fairbanks, trail experts and consultants in Alaska and throughout the U.S., graphic designers, architects, and more — have lent time and expertise to vet and develop the Trans-Alaska Trail vision. Energized by the vision, all private sector collaborators have worked pro bono.

After 17 months of diligence and hundreds (going on thousands) of hours of work, we’ve determined the Trans-Alaska Trail is feasible and viable. We’ve also identified myriad questions and concerns that merit answers and solutions. We’re excited to find those answers and create those solutions, and the path forward will require inclusive and collaborative stakeholder work, especially with Alyeska.

Chronology

The Trans-Alaska Trail team has:

  • reviewed state and federal right-of-way leases, Department of Homeland Security regulations, and multiple legal analyses to determine the compatibility of recreation along the right-of-way;
  • developed working partnerships with BLM Alaska, BLM leadership in D.C., Alaska DNR, communities and businesses along the trail corridor, local and national outdoor and recreation groups, national outdoor industry, trail consultants and experts, and Alaska adventure tourism sector;
  • initiated dialogue with Alyeska and discussed a solution-oriented path forward;
  • identified, ground-truthed, and photodocumented a 66-mile “pilot segment,” running from Valdez to the Little Tonsina River (mile 63 of the Richardson Highway). This pilot segment was chosen because of its spectacular scenic beauty, community support in Valdez, relative simplicity of land ownership, and because the pipeline runs underground for the entirety of the segment, mitigating security considerations;
  • identified capital improvements for sections of the Valdez-to-Little Tonsina pilot segment where the route is discontinuous (e.g., two large river crossings), and, working with trail consultants, estimated the cost of those capital improvements;
  • planned an open house in Valdez to broaden the community conversation on the Trans-Alaska Trail idea.
